intro: Xyris pterygoblephara, commonly known as the narrowleaf yellow-eyed grass, is a species of flowering plant in the family Xyridaceae. It is characterized by its grass-like appearance, with narrow, linear leaves and small, yellowish flowers arranged in spikelets. Native to the southeastern United States, it thrives in wetland and swampy environments. The plant typically grows to a height of about 10–30 centimeters and is often found in moist, acidic soils. Its botanical features make it an important component of wetland ecosystems.
